title_full:
Eiko Ishibashi

              —
              Evil Does Not Exist
            
              (Drag City)
label: Drag City
description:
Eiko Ishibashi's second collaboration with director Ryusuke Hamaguchi is a cryptic, serpentine rumination matching hazy, oddly-tuned drones with grandiose orchestral themes and energetic drum workouts. Remarkable stuff, the perfect follow-up to Ishibashi's beloved 'Drive My Car' score, with every nuance mixed & mastered by Jim O’Rourke.

When Ishibashi was asked to put together an A/V set for a series of overseas shows, she wondered if Hamaguchi might want to collaborate. She'd been... more

label: ANA
description:
Cult UK label ANA back with a compilation of grubby post-punk industrial, flying steppers, and restless, dank techno mutations as their first move of 2024 - RIYL Regis, Lost Domain, Sam Kerridge

Founded in 2018, ANA has ushered a slew of darkside rollers and steppers by the likes of Beyaz, Gamba, Bearer, and Kesa gate in its time. After a quiet 2023, they return to upend an archive of work produced 1997-2008 in Hamburg & London by a host of little known operators (perhaps the same... more

label: ESCHO
description:
Chinah's Fine, aka the sampled voice on Two Shell's 'Home', comes correct on her debut solo album, focusing her songwriting and coming up with a deceptively minimal, electronically-enhanced vision of homespun folk-pop - somewhere between Mazzy Star and ML Buch.

Even though 'Rocky Top Ballads' is Fine's first fully fleshed-out solo offering, she operates from the center of Denmark's fertile alt-pop scene. One half of Coined alongside Astrid Sonne, a part of Clarissa Connelly's Canons group... more

label: ESCHO
description:
Following in the footsteps of her college classmates Astrid Sonne, Clarissa Connelly, Erika de Casier and ML Buch, Danish-Chilean artist Rebecca Molina eyes pop thru an experimental lens on her debut album, intermingling MBV-style shoegaze with jerky, distorted trip-hop and sublime ambience.

There's definitely something in the water right now in Denmark. Molina's debut album, written while she was pregnant, is familiar, but not because it sounds like her peers' output, exactly. It's her... more

title_full:
Jabu

              —
              A Soft and Gatherable Star
            
              (do you have peace?)
label: do you have peace?
description:
Jabu take a big leap skyward on a gorgeous new album of hazed dreampop and burnished bass inspired by classic Cocteau Twins via A.R. Kane - essential listening for fans of HTRK, Rat Heart Ensemble, YL Hooi.

Launching with a dampened crash and slo-mo thuds, 'Oceanside Spider House' is the ideal re-introduction to the Bristol trio of Amos Childs, Alex Rendall and Jasmine Butt, who built a cult following for their blown-out, hypnagogic dub diffractions on 2017's 'Sleep Heavy' for Blackest... more

title_full:
Clarissa Connelly

              —
              World of Work
            
              (Warp Records)
label: Warp Records
description:
Inspired by French philosophy, medieval letters and romantic poetry, Clarissa Connelly's first Warp full-length is an ornate lattice of Celtic and Scandinavian history and mythology, packed with heady prog-folk epics that tumble into church bell snippets and ambient choral workouts. Ambitious stuff, and all the better for it - RIYL Kate Bush, Julia Holter or ML Buch.

We've been drip-fed pieces of this one for months at this point, and thankfully the album itself is worth the wait. It works best in... more

label: 4AD
description:
Widening the aspect ratio and raising the budget, Portuguese-Danish prodigy Erika de Casier retains her tight grip on R&B nostalgia with 'Still', simultaneously poking around reggaetón and PinkPantheress-style soft jungle. It's more effortlessly intimate, club-friendly gear that'll be haunting ur mind long after it's finished - featuring guest spots from Shygirl, Blood Orange and They Hate Change.

'Lucky' might be driven by modish minced, jungly breakbeats, but look under the hood and you'll... more

title_full:
Good Sad Happy Bad

              —
              All Kinds of Days
            
              (Textile)
label: Textile
description:
Mica Levi and pals’ scuzzy indie/art-pop unit speak to tight bonds developed over 15 years with their second LP as Good Sad Happy Bad, the latest iteration of an ensemble fka Micachu & The Shapes, whose catalogue arguably paved the way for a new phalanx of London shapeshifters over the past decade.

Raisa Khan, CJ Calderwood, and Marc Pell rejoin Mica Levi on a particularly lo-fi intimate and shruggingly optimistic album that sensitively, soberly deals with themes of “loss... more
